children.name: sth that makes you feel worried or unhappy
problem
children.definition: sth that happens in your life that makes you feel worried, unhappy: vấn đề

children.name: have problems
examples: Bill isn’t sleeping well - I think he’s having problems at school.

children.name: personal problems
examples: She’s had a lot of personal problems - her mother died when she was eight.

children.name: troubles
children.definition: things that make you feel worried and unhappy, especially problems that have continued for a long time: điều lo lắng
examples: It’s nice to talk to someone about your troubles.
Parents can get wrapped up in their own troubles, and not notice how it’s affecting their children.
Hepoured outall histroublesto me(= told me all about his problems ).

children.name: problem
children.definition: a bad situation that must be dealt with, because it is causing harm or inconvenience, or it is stopping you from doing what you want to do: vấn đề
examples: She was older than me, but that wasn’t really a problem.
problem of
The problem of street crime is getting worse every year.
problem with
I’ve been having a few problems with my car.
RegisterIn writing, people sometimes prefer to use the wordissuerather thanproblem, as it sounds more neutral and less negative:
theissueof race relations
the drug/crime etc problem
Federal laws have almost no effect on the crime problem that concerns most people - crime on the streets.
COMMON ERRORS
►It is more usual to saya big problem,a major problemora serious problem, instead of saying'an important problem'.

children.name: have a problem
examples: We saw water rushing in and realised we had a serious problem.

children.name: cause/create a problem
examples: The building’s lack of parking space could cause problems.

children.name: present/pose a problem
children.definition: cause it or make it have to be considered
examples: A shortage of trained nurses is posing major problems.

children.name: deal with/sort out a problem
examples: The state has failed to deal with the problem of violence against women.

children.name: tackle/address a problem
children.definition: deal with it
examples: There is more than one way to tackle this problem.

children.name: solve/resolve a problem
children.definition: alsofix a probleminformal
examples: He solved his financial problems by selling his car.

children.name: overcome a problem
examples: We try to help families overcome housing problems.

children.name: face a problem
examples: Terrorism is possibly the most important problem facing western countries.

children.name: raise a problem
children.definition: mention it, so that people can discuss it
examples: He also raised the problem of noise from planes taking off and landing.

children.name: encounter/experience a problem
examples: You shouldn’t encounter any further problems.

children.name: a problem arises/occurs
children.definition: alsoa problem comes up
examples: (= it happens )Problems may arise when the family wants to move house.

children.name: compound/exacerbate a problemformal
children.definition: make it worse
examples: The country’s economic problems are compounded by its ageing population.

children.name: the problem lies in/with sth
examples: The problem lies in the design of the rocket.

children.name: big/major/serious
examples: The school’s biggest problem is a shortage of cash.

children.name: little/small/minor
examples: Old cars often develop minor engine problems.

children.name: the main problem
examples: The main problem for the climbers was lack of sleep.

children.name: a real problem
examples: They quickly found that their real problem lay with marketing.

children.name: a difficult problem
examples: Does the team have the skills to tackle these difficult problems?

children.name: a thorny/knotty problem
children.definition: difficult
examples: He still faced the thorny problem of finding a way out of the jungle.

children.name: a fundamental problem
children.definition: relating to the most basic and important parts of something
examples: The government has done little to solve the fundamental problems of poverty and crime.

children.name: a pressing problem
children.definition: one that needs to be dealt with very soon
examples: Lack of clean drinking water is the most pressing problem facing the refugees.

children.name: personal problems
children.definition: relating to your private life and relationships
examples: My daughter found it hard to talk about her personal problems.

children.name: family problems
examples: She would never discuss family problems with outsiders.

children.name: financial/money problems
examples: Our financial problems are over.

children.name: economic problems
examples: He argued that the government was to blame for the country’s economic problems.

children.name: a technical problem
examples: The delay was caused by technical problems.

children.name: a practical problem
examples: Burying a pet can present practical problems.

children.name: an environmental problem
examples: Air pollution is our most serious environmental problem.

children.name: trouble
children.definition: (alsotroubles ) problems or difficulties

children.name: have trouble
examples: He is having trouble getting his message across to the voters.

children.name: have no trouble
examples: We had no trouble finding her house.

children.name: cause trouble
examples: I hope the delay hasn’t caused you any trouble.

children.name: there is trouble
examples: There was some trouble at her office, but she didn’t say what it was.

children.name: mean/spell trouble
children.definition: mean there will be trouble
examples: They are now much more competitive, which can only spell trouble for their rivals.

children.name: be asking for trouble
children.definition: be silly or dangerous
examples: It 's asking for trouble to wear high-heeled shoes on a long walk.

children.name: avoid trouble
examples: We avoid trouble by planning carefully.

children.name: big/great trouble
examples: High interest rates spell big trouble for homeowners.

children.name: terrible trouble
examples: I’ve been having terrible trouble sleeping.

children.name: endless trouble
children.definition: a lot of trouble
examples: They had endless trouble with the water supply.

children.name: serious trouble
examples: I was having serious trouble knowing where to begin.

children.name: teething troublesBritish English
children.definition: small problems that you have when you first start doing a new job or using a new system
examples: There were a lot of teething troubles in the first year.

children.name: what the trouble is
examples: A couple of nurses rushed into the room to see what the trouble was.

children.name: without any/much trouble
children.definition: easily
examples: The work was carried out without any trouble.

children.name: trouble with
examples: We’re having a lot of trouble with the new computer system.
Recent stock market losses point to trouble ahead.

children.name: difficulty
children.definition: a problem or sth that causes trouble

children.name: have difficulties
examples: By the age of eight, Robbie was having difficulties at school.

children.name: run into/get into difficulties
children.definition: find yourself in a difficult situation
examples: Three people were rescued from a boat that had got into difficulties.

children.name: experience/encounter difficultiesformal
children.definition: have difficulties
examples: Graduates often experience considerable difficulties in getting their first job.

children.name: face difficulties
examples: The hotel’s owners were facing financial difficulties.

children.name: overcome/resolve difficulties
children.definition: deal with them successfully
examples: We are confident that we can overcome these difficulties.

children.name: present/pose difficultiesformal
children.definition: be something that is difficult to deal with
examples: English spelling may present some difficulties for learners.

children.name: be fraught with difficulties
children.definition: involve a lot of them
examples: The whole plan was fraught with difficulties.

children.name: cause/lead to difficulties
examples: Stress and worry both cause sleep difficulties.

children.name: give rise to difficultiesformal
children.definition: cause them
examples: The stormy weather gave rise to difficulties for many of the competitors in the yacht race.

children.name: difficulties arise
children.definition: happen
examples: It’s best to discuss any difficulties that arise rather than trying to deal with them alone.

children.name: major/serious/severe difficulties
examples: By then, we were having serious financial difficulties.

children.name: considerable difficulties
children.definition: a lot of problems
examples: They had considerable difficulties in getting funding for their research.

children.name: technical difficulties
examples: The flight was delayed due to technical difficulties.

children.name: practical difficulties
children.definition: problems with doing something
examples: It’s a great idea, but there will be a number of practical difficulties.

children.name: financial/economic difficulties
examples: The company is facing serious financial difficulties.

children.name: breathing difficulties
examples: She was taken to hospital with breathing difficulties.

children.name: marital difficulties
children.definition: in a marriage
examples: You may need help in dealing with your marital difficulties.

children.name: difficulty with
examples: There are several difficulties with this theory.
If you have any difficulties, give me a call.
The project soon ran into difficulties.
Difficulties can arise when there is more than one defendant.

children.name: hassle
children.definition: informala problem or a series of problems that are annoying because they involve a lot of work, arguing, inconvenience etc:rắc rối
examples: I don’t feel like cooking tonight, it’s too much hassle.
It’s such a hassle not having a washing machine.

children.name: a real hassle
children.definition: used to emphasize that something is very annoying or causes a lot of problems
examples: Carrying a heavy bag around all day is a real hassle.

children.name: a big hassle
examples: I find putting on make-up a big hassle.

children.name: legal/bureaucratic/administrative hassle
examples: It took weeks of bureaucratic hassle to get a replacement passport.

children.name: get hassle
children.definition: be made to experience problems
examples: Liz is getting a lot of hassle about the claim from her insurance company.

children.name: have hassle
children.definition: experience problems
examples: If we book now, we won’t have the hassle of picking up the tickets at the box office.

children.name: give sb hassle
children.definition: make someone experience problems
examples: Did the teacher give you any hassle about that homework?

children.name: avoid hassle
examples: Many couples get married abroad to avoid the hassle and cost of a big wedding.

children.name: it’s not worth the hassle
children.definition: something is not worth doing because it involves a lot of problems
examples: I’m not going to argue with him – it’s just not worth the hassle.

children.name: it’s too much hassle
examples: I don’t want to organize a big party - it’s too much hassle.

children.name: take the hassle out of something
children.definition: remove the problems related to doing something
examples: The internet takes all the hassle out of shopping.

children.name: go through the hassle of doing something
children.definition: experience the problems of doing something
examples: The shirt didn’t fit so I had to go through the hassle of taking it back to the shop.

children.name: snag
children.definition: a problem or disadvantage, especially one that is not very serious, which you had not expected :trở ngại
examples: It’s an interesting job.Theonlysnag is thatit’s not very well paid.
The cleanup effort was delayed for a few days by some technical snags and equipment problems.

children.name: hit/run into a snag
examples: The grand opening hit a snag when no one could find the key.

children.name: last-minute snag
examples: The House worked out some last-minute snags in the legislation.
Register Snagis slightly informal. In written English, people usually prefer to useproblemordisadvantageinstead:
The onlydisadvantageis that it takes a little longer.

children.name: complication
children.definition: an additional problem that makes a situation even harder to deal with than it already is : phức tạp, rắc rối
examples: One complication is that the meals also need to be suitable for children of Islamic or Jewish faiths.
Legal and financial complications have made it impossible for the two companies to complete the deal on time.
Dave couldn't find his passport at the airport and then there werefurthercomplications when Fiona lost her baggage.
If any complicationsarise, let me know and I'll help.

children.name: hitch
children.definition: a small problem that makes sth difficult or delays it for a short time : vướng mắc, kẹt

children.name: technical/slight/last-minute hitch
examples: In spite of some technical hitches, the first program was a success.
There’s been a slight technical hitch, so we’ll have to postpone the video until later.

children.name: without a hitchwithout any problems
examples: The whole show went without a hitch .

children.name: there’s a hitch
examples: There was a hitch - about half the employees did not want to move to a different city.

children.name: hitch in
examples: Nelson refused to comment on reports of a last-minute hitch in the negotiations.
RegisterIn written English, people usually prefer to use(small/minor) problemrather thanhitch, which sounds slightly informal:
There were someminor technical problemswhen the product was first released.

children.name: teething troubles
children.definition: /pains/problemsBritishsmall problems that a new company, product, system etc has at the beginning : ban đầu, "mọc răng"
examples: After a few teething troubles, the new car worked perfectly.
The disagreement was just one of the teething problems of the partnership.

children.name: catch
children.definition: a hidden problem or disadvantage in an offer that seems very good - use this especially when you think the problem has been deliberately hidden to trick people : “gài, móc, bẫy”

children.name: there’s a catch
examples: You get free meals and accommodation, but there’s a catch -- you have to look after the children.

children.name: with a catch
examples: Many of the best deals come with a catch: they are only good through early summer.

children.name: the catch is (that)
examples: The catch is that you can’t enter the contest unless you have spent $50 in the store.

children.name: hiccup
children.definition: a small problem which is not very important compared to other things : “nấc” trục trặc
examples: There was a slight hiccup when I couldn’t find my car keys, but finally we set off.

children.name: hiccup in
examples: The airline industry’s troubles are a mere hiccup in an otherwise upward growth trend.

children.name: how to explain about a problem
the problem is
children.definition: the trouble/problem is poken say this when you are explaining why something is difficult or what is causing problems: vấn đề là
examples: ▪ The trouble is, there’s no-one here who really understands computers.

children.name: the trouble/problem is (that)
examples: ▪ The problem is that we can’t really afford the plane fare.

children.name: the trouble/problem with sth is
examples: ▪ The trouble with using credit cards is that it’s so easy to get into debt.

children.name: the thing is
children.definition: spoken informal say this when you are explaining to a friend why you cannot do what they want: chuyện là
examples: ▪ The thing is, I have an important exam next week.
▪ I’d love to come, but the thing is, I promised to see Jim tonight.

children.name: the trouble is
children.definition: 2 bad point used when saying what is bad about a person or situation or what causes problems :
examples: The trouble withyouis thatyou don’t listen.
The trouble isthere are too many people and not enough places.
But no one ever remembers –that’s the trouble.
You never think,that’syourtrouble.

children.name: a problem that stops you from making progress
setback
children.definition: a problem that delays or prevents progress, or makes things worse than they were : trở ngại
examples: Arafat has survived crises, setbacks, and challenges to his leadership.

children.name: suffer a setback
examples: The team suffered a serious setback when the goalkeeper went off injured.

children.name: receive a setback
examples: The islands’ economy had received a severe setback from the effects of hurricane Hugo.

children.name: a major setback
examples: Losing our key player would be a major setback for the team.

children.name: a big/serious/severe setback
examples: This is a serious setback to the company.

children.name: a minor setback
children.definition: not very bad
examples: It was only a minor setback.

children.name: a temporary setback
children.definition: lasting only a short time
examples: Try not to be discouraged by temporary setbacks.

children.name: an early/initial setback
children.definition: happening quite soon
examples: The policy has been successful, despite some early setbacks.

children.name: a political/military/economic setback
examples: The defeat represented a major political setback for the conservatives.

children.name: a business/election etc setback
examples: He had been depressed over a number of business setbacks.

children.name: setback for
examples: The December elections were a major setback for the party.

children.name: setback in
examples: Manning suffered a setback in his battle against alcoholism.

children.name: hurdle
children.definition: a problem or difficulty that must be dealt with before you can do or achieve something else:rào cản
examples: ▪ The main hurdle at present is getting the council’s permission.

children.name: legal/bureaucratic/political etc hurdle
examples: ▪ Women face a lot of legal hurdles trying to prove sexual harassment.
▪ There are lots of bureaucratic hurdles to deal with when adopting a child.

children.name: hurdle for
examples: ▪ Requiring school uniforms can be a financial hurdle for the poor.

children.name: clear/pass a hurdle
examples: ▪ The bill has cleared all the hurdles before it and will soon become law.

children.name: stumbling block
children.definition: a fact or situation that will make it very difficult for sth to be achieved: khó khăn
examples: ▪ Negotiations with management broke off Tuesday, with wage proposals the stumbling block.

children.name: stumbling block to
examples: ▪ Each side has accused the others of creating stumbling blocks to peace.

children.name: stumbling block for
examples: ▪ Mortgage interest rates have fallen, but large down payments remain a stumbling block for house buyers.

children.name: hindrance
children.definition: sth that makes it very difficult for you to do what you are trying to do: sự cản trở
examples: ▪ America’s top golfers played well despite the hindrance of early morning mist.
▪ I concentrated on my career, feeling that a family would be a hindrance.

children.name: be a hindrance to
examples: ▪ The country’s poor infrastructure is a major hindrance to importers.
▪ The biggest hindrance to economic reform has been the lack of access to U.S. markets.

children.name: without hindrance
examples: ▪ Travelers can move through the country without hindrance.

children.name: more of a hindrance than a helpcausing more problems than there would be otherwise
examples: ▪ The girls wanted to set the table, but they were more of a hindrance than a help.

children.name: obstacle
children.definition: a difficult problem that stops sb or sth making progress or developing: trở ngại, “chướng ngại vật”
examples: The deal should go through, but there are several legal obstacles to overcome first.
There are a number of obstacles in the way of a lasting peace settlement.

children.name: be an obstacle
examples: This issue is a major obstacle to a successful peace treaty.

children.name: prove an obstacle
children.definition: be an obstacle
examples: The weather proved an obstacle, with nonstop rains flooding the field.

children.name: present/pose an obstacle
children.definition: cause an obstacle to exist
examples: Serious differences continue to present obstacles to an agreement.|Our reliance on fossil fuels poses an obstacle to achieving these targets.

children.name: overcome an obstacle
children.definition: alsosurmount an obstacleformal
examples: (= find a solution to an obstacle )We need to help young people overcome the obstacles that poverty puts in their way.

children.name: remove an obstacle
examples: Opening the border removed all obstacles to trade and travel between the two countries.

children.name: face an obstacle
children.definition: have to deal with an obstacle
examples: The investigation has faced numerous obstacles.

children.name: encounter an obstacle
children.definition: find that there is an obstacle
examples: People should not encounter obstacles because of their age, sex, race, or religion.

children.name: put/place obstacles in the way
children.definition: try to stop someone from doing something easily
examples: Her father put several obstacles in the way of their marriage.

children.name: a major/serious obstacle
examples: Debt is a major obstacle to economic growth.|There are serious obstacles to obtaining sufficient funding.

children.name: a real obstacle
children.definition: a serious one
examples: The lack of oil and gas resources in Northeast Asia is a real obstacle to the region's economic development.

children.name: the main/biggest/greatest etc obstacle
examples: The biggest obstacle to women's equality was social expectations of male and female roles.

children.name: an insuperable/insurmountable obstacle
children.definition: one that it is impossible to find a solution to
examples: The problem does not present an insurmountable obstacle.|There are no insuperable obstacles to the purchase of the company.

children.name: a formidable obstacle
children.definition: one that makes it very difficult to achieve something
examples: There are formidable obstacles to legal reform.

children.name: a legal/political/technical etc obstacle
examples: Despite technical obstacles, scientists at NASA are considering the project.

children.name: an obstacle in the way/path
examples: There were still a number of obstacles in the way of an agreement.

children.name: obstacle to
examples: Fear of change is an obstacle to progress.

children.name: how to ask sb about a problem
what’s up
children.definition: /ˌwɒts ˈʌp/spokeninformal say this when you are asking someone if there is a problem that they want to talk about:chuyện gì vậy
examples: ▪ ‘Karen, can I talk to you for a minute?’ ‘Sure, what’s up?’
what’s up with somebody?say this when someone seems to have a problem
có chuyện gì với ai đó?
▪ What’s up with Larry today?

children.name: what’s the problem
children.definition: spoken say this when you are asking why sb cannot do sth or why sth will not work: có vấn đề gì sao?
examples: ▪ ‘I can’t finish the last question.’ ‘Why? What’s the problem?’
▪ What’s the problem? Is there something I can do?
what’s the problem with
▪ ‘I can’t get my computer to work.’ ‘What’s the problem with it?’

children.name: do you have a problem with that?
children.definition: especially US, spoken say this to ask sb if they are unhappy about sth you just said or suggested - use this when you are annoyed and want to be slightly rude: bạn có vấn đề với nó sao?
examples: ‘Is he going to sleep in your room?’ ‘I think so. Do you have a problem with that?’
‘Are you all by yourself?’ I said, ‘Yes.’ And I wanted to say ‘you got a problem with that?’

children.name: what’s the matter
children.definition: /what’s wrongB1 spoken say this when you are asking someone what is causing a problem, for example why they are upset, or why a machine will not work: có vấn đề gì sao?
examples: ▪ What’s the matter? You look as if you’ve been crying.

children.name: what’s wrong/what’s the matter with
examples: ▪ What’s wrong with the TV?
▪ What was the matter with Daniella yesterday?

children.name: an extremely difficult or complicated problem
dilemma
children.definition: a situation in which it is very difficult to decide what to do, because all the choices seem equally good or equally bad: tiến thoái lưỡng nan, khó xử
examples: It is a common dilemma: Should you stay where you have friends and family, or take that good job in a far-away city?
a moral dilemma
in a dilemma
I’m in a dilemma about this job offer.

children.name: be in a dilemma
examples: After years of recession, the company was in a dilemma over its future.

children.name: face a dilemma/be faced with a dilemma
examples: Women may still be faced with the dilemma of choosing between jobs and families.

children.name: pose/create a dilemma
examples: The difficult economic situation poses a dilemma for investors.

children.name: put/place somebody in a dilemma
examples: His divided loyalties placed him in a dilemma.

children.name: resolve/solve a dilemma
examples: People often need help with resolving their dilemmas.

children.name: explain your dilemma
children.definition: talk about it
examples: He explained his dilemma to me.

children.name: a difficult/serious dilemma
examples: He was in a serious dilemma because neither option seemed very desirable.

children.name: a terrible dilemma
examples: She was in a terrible dilemma because she loved both men.

children.name: a moral/ethical/political etc dilemma
examples: Doctors face a moral dilemma over how long to prolong someone's life.

children.name: a personal dilemma
examples: The men who were on strike faced a personal dilemma over whether to return to work.

children.name: a painful dilemma
children.definition: a very difficult one
examples: She faced the painful dilemma of having to decide whether to tell the police about her son's crimes.

children.name: a common/familiar dilemma
children.definition: one that a lot of people have
examples: Deciding whether to put an elderly parent in a nursing home is a common dilemma.

children.name: the central dilemma
children.definition: the main one
examples: The Prime Minister's central dilemma was whether war was justified.

children.name: a way out of a dilemma
children.definition: a way to solve it
examples: There seemed to be no way out of the dilemma.

children.name: a solution to a dilemma
children.definition: a way to solve it
examples: One possible solution to the dilemma may be to divide the money equally betweeen the brothers.

children.name: catch-22
children.definition: a situation in which you cannot do one thing until you do another thing, but you cannot do that thing until you do the first thing, with the result that you can do neither: nan giải
examples: It’s catch-22 -- she can’t get a job unless she has experience, and she can’t get experience unless she has a job.

children.name: a catch-22 situation
examples: It’s a catch-22 situation: The project won’t receive government money until it is shown to be successful, but it cannot be successful without adequate funds.

children.name: no-win
children.definition: situation a situation in which sth bad will happen whatever you decide to do:thế kẹt,
examples: It’s a no-win situation -- if I tell him, he’ll be upset, but if I don’t he’ll be mad at me for not telling him.
Hospitals are in a no-win situation, since protecting patients’ privacy may conflict with protecting the health of doctors, nurses, and other hospital workers.

children.name: chicken-and-egg
children.definition: a  problem/situation/dilemma a difficult situation in which you do not know which of two things was the cause of the other and which was the result, because neither could exist if the other did not:chuyện con gà và quả trứng
examples: We all hate lawyers, but they’re in business because so many people sue each other: it’s a classic chicken-and-egg situation.
The airport faces a chicken-and-egg dilemma: Airlines won’t add more flights unless there is more demand, and there won’t be more demand until there are more flights.

children.name: vicious circle
children.definition: a situation in which one problem causes another problem, that then causes the first problem again, so that the whole process continues to be repeated:vòng lẩn quẩn
examples: Many people who diet put on even more weight when they stop, creating a vicious circle.
More and more teenagers are caught in a vicious circle of drug addiction and crime.

children.name: problematic
children.definition: full of problems and difficult to deal with: khó giải quyết
examples: It is important to understand the problematic nature of historical evidence.
The new salary scale remains a problematic area.

children.name: highly problematic
examples: The Foreign Minister said that relations between the two countries are ‘highly problematic’.

children.name: fraught with
children.definition: problems/difficulties use this about an activity or plan that is full of unexpected problems which make it very difficult: đầy những khó khăn
examples: The preparations for the wedding were fraught with difficulties, but finally everything went well.
Legalization of drugs would be fraught with problems, but the ‘war on drugs’ causes problems too.

children.name: minefield
children.definition: an activity or subject where you have to be very careful, because it is full of hidden problems and risks, so that it is very easy to make mistakes or upset people: "bãi mìn"
examples: House-buying can be a minefield -- you need a good lawyer.
Mozart’s music seems so danceable, but most choreographers regard it as a minefield.

children.name: can of worms
children.definition: informal a situation or subject which at first seems to be simple and easy to deal with, but is full of complicated problems for anyone who gets involved with it: chuyện rắc rối, "hộp giun"
examples: Census questions about race are a pretty big can of worms.

children.name: open up a can of wormssuddenly find that you have to deal with a lot of difficult and unexpected problems
examples: The government opened up a can of worms when it decided to reorganize the education system.

children.name: problem
children.definition: sth wrong with your health or with part of your body

children.name: a health/medical problem
examples: Have you ever suffered from any of these health problems?

children.name: a back/heart/kidney etc problem
examples: He was born with heart problems.

children.name: a hearing problem
examples: There are special telephones for people with hearing problems.

children.name: a weight problem
children.definition: the problem of being too fat
examples: Patients with weight problems were put on a strict diet.

children.name: psychological problems
children.definition: alsomental health problems
examples: She is being treated for psychological problems at a mental hospital in Oxford.

children.name: emotional problems
examples: He suffers from depression and other emotional problems.

children.name: behavioural problems
examples: Many of these children have behavioural problems.

children.name: a serious/major problem
examples: Lifting things carelessly can lead to serious back problems.

children.name: a minor problem
examples: She has had some minor medical problems.

children.name: have a problem
examples: He's always had a weight problem.

children.name: suffer
children.definition: from
examples: a problemThe patient began to suffer breathing problems.

children.name: health problem/problem with your health
examples: Does she have any long-term health problems?

children.name: problem
children.definition: sth wrong with your health or with part of your body

children.name: a health/medical problem
examples: Have you ever suffered from any of these health problems?

children.name: a back/heart/kidney etc problem
examples: He was born with heart problems.

children.name: a hearing problem
examples: There are special telephones for people with hearing problems.

children.name: a weight problem
children.definition: the problem of being too fat
examples: Patients with weight problems were put on a strict diet.

children.name: psychological problems
children.definition: alsomental health problems
examples: She is being treated for psychological problems at a mental hospital in Oxford.

children.name: emotional problems
examples: He suffers from depression and other emotional problems.

children.name: behavioural problems
examples: Many of these children have behavioural problems.

children.name: a serious/major problem
examples: Lifting things carelessly can lead to serious back problems.

children.name: a minor problem
examples: She has had some minor medical problems.

children.name: have a problem
examples: He's always had a weight problem.

children.name: suffer
children.definition: from
examples: a problemThe patient began to suffer breathing problems.

children.name: health problem/problem with your health
examples: Does she have any long-term health problems?

children.name: trouble
children.definition: a problem that you have with your health :
examples: Hehas trouble withhis breathing.

children.name: heart/stomach/skin etc trouble
examples: He suffers from back trouble.

children.name: trouble
children.definition: when sth is wrong with a machine, vehicle, or system :
examples: engine trouble
trouble with
He had to retire from the race because of trouble with the gearbox.

children.name: trouble
children.definition: 3 bad situation in/into/out of
examples: a)if someone or something is in trouble, they are in a situation with a lot of problems :
He admitted that their marriage was in trouble.
get/run into trouble
The company ran into trouble when it tried to expand too quickly.
in serious/deep trouble
The economy was in serious trouble.
the dangers of trying to borrow your way out of trouble
b)if someone is in trouble, they have done something which someone will punish them for or be angry about
in deep/big trouble
We’ll be in big trouble if Mr Elliott finds out.
in trouble with somebody
I think I’m in trouble with Dad.
I didn’t say anything because I didn’t want toget into trouble.
keep/stay out of trouble
I hope Tim stays out of trouble this year.

children.name: difficulty
children.definition: 1 if you have  doing something, it is difficult for you to do
examples: have/experience difficulty (in) doing something
They hadgreat difficultyin finding a replacement.
with/without difficulty
He got to his feet with difficulty.
►Do not say that someone ‘has difficulty to do something’. Say that someonehas difficulty doing somethingorhas difficulty in doing something.
2[U] the quality of being difficult to do
the difficulty of (doing) something
the difficulty of solving such problems
3[U] how difficult sth is :
The tests vary in difficulty.

children.name: be in the clear
children.definition: to have no problems after being in a difficult situation
examples: The X-rays showed that she's in the clear.

children.name: tip of the iceberg
children.definition: a small noticeable part of a problem, the total size of which is really much greater
examples: These small local protests are just the tip of the iceberg.

children.name: challenge
children.definition: sth that tests strength, skill, or ability, especially in a way that is interesting : thử thách

children.name: meet a challenge
children.definition: deal with one
examples: Here are a few tips to help you meet the challenges of university life.

children.name: face a challenge
children.definition: have to deal with one
examples: The company still faces some challenges.

children.name: accept a challenge
children.definition: try to deal with one
examples: He was ready to accept new challenges.

children.name: take on a challenge
children.definition: accept one
examples: The new headteacher has taken on the challenge of improving the school.

children.name: present/pose a challenge
children.definition: be a difficult one
examples: These changes pose a real challenge to farmers.

children.name: provide a challenge
children.definition: be an interesting one
examples: Her new job provided a real challenge.

children.name: rise to a challenge
children.definition: deal successfully with it
examples: It was a difficult project but we rose to the challenge.

children.name: love/enjoy/relish a challenge
examples: Children enjoy a challenge so the work should not be too easy.

children.name: a big/major/huge/tremendous challenge
examples: Building the tunnel presented a major challenge to engineers.

children.name: a serious challenge
examples: At the moment we are facing a serious environmental challenge.

children.name: a real challenge
children.definition: a difficult one
examples: On Monday, Sharapova faced her first real challenge of the tournament.

children.name: a formidable/daunting/tough challenge
children.definition: a very difficult one
examples: How to deal with waste is a daunting challenge for the west.

children.name: the biggest challenge of something
examples: This could be the biggest challenge of his career.

children.name: an intellectual/physical/technical etc challenge
examples: I love the physical challenge of climbing.

children.name: challenge of
examples: The company is ready to meet the challenges of the next few years.

children.name: the challenge of doing something
examples: I relish the challenge of rebuilding the club.

children.name: torture
children.definition: informal a very unpleasant experience : “sự tra tấn”
examples: The rush-hour traffic wassheertorture as usual.
The waiting must be torture for you.

children.name: the final/last straw
children.definition: (alsothe straw that breaks the camel's back)

children.name: the last in a series of unpleasant events which finally makes you feel that you cannot continue to accept a bad situation
examples: Losing my job was bad enough, but being evicted from my house was the final straw.
She's always been rude to me, but it was the last straw when she started insulting my mother.

children.name: invasion
children.definition: noun
examples: an action or process which affects someone's life in an unpleasant and unwanted way
an invasionofprivacy

children.name: have a bumpy ride
children.definition: informal

children.name: to have a difficult time
examples: She's had a bumpy ride at work over the last few months.

children.name: the hard way
children.definition: If you learn something , you learn from unpleasant experiences rather than by being taught
examples: If she won't listen, she'll have tolearn/find outthe hard way.

children.name: rough ride
children.definition: a

children.name: a difficult time
examples: Government plans to cut sick pay had a rough ride in the House of Commons.
The construction industry is in for a rough ride this year.
